questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of hearing loss and unsteadiness while standing and walking for the past 2 months. She needs to support herself against a wall to avoid falling. She has not had any recent injuries and has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an unsteady gait. She sways when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is unable to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears or repeat words whispered in her ears. An MRI of the brain shows a 3-cm tumor in the right cerebellopontine angle and a 4.5-cm tumor in the left cerebellopontine angle. This patient should be counseled that she is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The occurrence of (bilateral) renal cell carcinoma is associated with von Hippel‑Lindau disease. This neurocutaneous syndrome is characterized by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumors, including hemangioblastomas (highly vascularized in the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine), pheochromocytomas, and renal and pancreatic cysts. Bilateral acoustic neuromas, however, are not a typical feature.

B) INCORRECT:

Telangiectasias on the face and conjunctivae are typical findings in patients with ataxia telangiectasia. Other manifestations include progressive cerebellar ataxia (due to atrophy of the cerebellar vermis), athetosis, immunodeficiency (e.g., increased susceptibility to ear infections, sinusitis, and pneumonia), and increased sensitivity to radiation resulting in a higher risk of malignancies (e.g. non-Hodgkin lymphoma, leukemia). However, the finding of bilateral acoustic neuromas is not typical in patients with ataxia telangiectasia. Furthermore, symptoms typically manifest during early childhood.

C) INCORRECT:

Vascular malformations of the choroid and the central nervous system such as ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas are a typical feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome. These malformations may result in seizures, early-onset glaucoma (due to increased intraorbital pressure), and intellectual disability. Patients also often present with a facial nevus flammeus (port-wine stain). However, acoustic neuromas are not associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; axial plane) of a patient with Sturge-Weber syndrome

Marked, leptomeningeal contrast enhancement along the right parieto-occipital gyri and sulci can be seen (green overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Other tumors that may occur in patients with NF1 include benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors originating from neural crest cells (neurofibromas), pheochromocytomas, and nephroblastomas. The presence of bilateral acoustic neuromas, however, is not associated with NF1. Moreover, patients with NF1 usually present with typical skin findings (due to melanocyte dysfunction) such as café au lait spots and axillary/inguinal freckling, as well as musculoskeletal findings (e.g., scoliosis, tall stature, and bone involvement) and Lisch nodules of the iris, none of which are seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

In addition to bilateral acoustic neuromas, which occur in almost all individuals with NF2 by the age of 30 years, NF2 can cause multiple tumors of the nervous system, such as intracranial and spinal meningiomas, schwannomas of other cranial nerves, and ependymomas. Most meningiomas are slow-growing and patients may therefore be asymptomatic for a prolonged period of time. If symptoms do occur, they usually include general symptoms of CNS tumors (e.g., seizures) or more specific symptoms that are determined by the location of the tumor (e.g., paraparesis and/or uncontrolled micturition if the tumor arises from the falx cerebri). Other typical clinical findings of NF2 include early-onset bilateral cataracts, seizures, skin nodules, and café au lait spots (see “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table).

The clinical features of acoustic neuromas are caused by compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) as a result of the tumor expanding into the internal acoustic meatus. Sensorineural hearing loss, which is the most common presenting symptom, and tinnitus are due to cochlear nerve involvement, whereas dizziness, unsteady gait, and disequilibrium indicate vestibular nerve involvement.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass (green overlay) along the cerebral convexity. It demonstrates intense, homogeneous enhancement, equivalent to that of adjacent dura mater. Displacement without invasion of the surrounding white matter supports an extra-axial location.

This is a case of meningioma, a dural-based tumor. The dura is represented in this image by the thin, discontinuously enhancing line covering the inner surface of the skull (indicated by arrowhead).

F) INCORRECT:

Giant cell astrocytomas are frequently associated with tuberous sclerosis. Other benign growths that frequently manifest in patients with tuberous sclerosis include hamartomas of the brain, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal cysts, renal angiomyolipomas, and ungual fibromas. The brain lesions typically result in infantile spasms (head bobbing, flexor or extensor spasms in children < 3 years of age), seizures, and intellectual disability. Furthermore, skin manifestations, such as adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, and a Shagreen patch are commonly seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis. However, acoustic neuromas are not a feature of tuberous sclerosis and the condition is usually diagnosed before the age of 10.
questions.hint: Hearing loss and impaired balance in combination with tumors in the cerebellopontine angles raise concern for acoustic neuromas. Bilateral acoustic neuromas are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss during the last 3 months. During this period, he has complained of abdominal pain and fullness, and his parents feel that he has been eating less. His parents also report that his urine has appeared pink for several weeks. He has been performing poorly in school lately, with reports from teachers that he has not been paying attention in class and has been distracting other students. He was born at term and has been healthy except for a history of several infantile seizures. His vital signs are within normal limits. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows a palpable abdominal mass, abdominal tenderness in the left upper quadrant, and left costovertebral angle tenderness. There are several ellipsoid, hypopigmented macules on the back and legs and a 4-cm raised plaque of rough, dimpled skin on the right lower back that is the same color as the surrounding skin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) typically manifests with hemangioblastomas (most often in the cerebellum, spinal cord, and/or retina), renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic cysts and tumors. This patient presents with a left-sided abdominal mass and a history suggestive of hematuria, which could be consistent with renal cell carcinoma. However, the lack of other characteristic tumors or malformations, along with the dermatological findings, which are not characteristic of VHL, make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by café au lait macules, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, and optic gliomas. NF1 can manifest with seizures and cognitive deficits and is associated with certain tumors such as nephroblastomas, which manifest with hematuria and a palpable abdominal mass. However, this patient presents with ash-leaf spots and Shagreen patches, which are not features of NF1.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is characterized by a “port-wine stain”, which is caused by facial capillary malformations and is usually located over the forehead and upper eyelid. This cutaneous finding is accompanied by neurologic disturbances such as seizures, intellectual disability, and focal neurological deficits (paresis, visual field defects). While this patient's history of seizures, behavioral problems, and declining performance at school could represent neurological manifestations of SWS, he lacks the characteristic port-wine stain and ocular involvement. Moreover, his dermatological and renal involvement is not consistent with SWS.

D) CORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis (TSC) is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by the presence of benign hamartomas, which cause a wide variety of symptoms depending on the organs involved. Hamartomas may manifest in the skin as shagreen patches, angiofibromas, and ash-leaf spots; in the CNS, with secondary seizures, hydrocephalus, and/or intellectual disability; in the kidney, as angiomyolipomas (which may cause pain and impairment of renal function), benign cysts, or renal cell carcinoma. This patient's dermatological findings alone are not sufficient to diagnose TSC, but his history and physical examination findings, with macrohematuria, abdominal pain and fullness, left-sided abdominal mass, and costovertebral angle tenderness, suggest the presence of one or more angiomyolipomas. Furthermore, he has a history of seizures, cognitive deficits, and behavioral problems that may be associated with TSC.

See “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) most frequently manifests with (bilateral) acoustic/vestibular schwannomas, along with schwannomas of other cranial nerves, intracranial meningiomas, and spinal and peripheral nerve tumors. The condition is typically diagnosed when tumors appear in late adolescence or early adulthood. While cutaneous manifestations may be present in NF2, ash-leaf spots and Shagreen patches are not typically seen. Moreover, this patient's history and physical examination findings imply the presence of renal, behavioral, and cognitive abnormalities, which are not consistent with a diagnosis of NF2.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.
questions.hint: This child presents with ash-leaf spots (hypopigmented macules on the trunk and extremities) and a shagreen patch (flesh-colored papule in the lumbosacral region).

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has been having difficulties with his schoolwork over the past 4 years. He has a seizure disorder treated with valproic acid. He was able to walk independently at the age of 3 years and was able to use a fork and spoon at the age of 4 years. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple freckles in the axillary and groin skin folds as well as scoliosis. There are 14 hyperpigmented macules over the back and chest. There are multiple soft, painless nodules over the extremities and the trunk. Ophthalmic examination shows hyperpigmented iris nodules bilaterally. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Individuals with NF1 are at increased risk for developing benign and/or malignant nervous system tumors, especially optic gliomas. Because optic gliomas are often asymptomatic, all children with NF1 should undergo an annual ophthalmologic examination and have a brain and orbit MRI if they develop symptoms associated with this tumor (e.g., decreased visual acuity, proptosis, strabismus, precocious puberty). Individuals with NF1 are also at increased risk of developing pheochromocytoma and nephroblastoma.

See “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) are at increased risk of developing (especially bilateral) vestibular schwannoma. NF2 typically manifests with complications of schwannomas (e.g., hearing loss, balance problems) and may cause other tumors of the central nervous system (e.g., meningioma). Hyperpigmented iris nodules and cognitive impairment, as seen in this patient, are not associated with NF2.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with ataxia telangiectasia are at increased risk of developing non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Ataxia telangiectasia should be suspected in patients with progressive cerebellar ataxia (due to cerebellar atrophy), athetosis, telangiectasias on the face and conjunctivae, and immunodeficiency (e.g. recurrent upper respiratory infections). This patient's skin findings and developmental delay are not typically seen in ataxia telangiectasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with Sturge-Weber syndrome are at increased risk of developing glaucoma due to increased intraorbital pressure. Patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome typically have vascular malformations of the choroid and central nervous system (which can also cause seizures), e.g., leptomeningeal angioma, and intellectual disabilities. However, cutaneous findings include facial port-wine stains, not skin fold freckling and café au lait spots.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with von Hippel-Lindau disease are at increased risk of developing (especially bilateral) renal cell carcinoma. Patients generally present with renal and pancreatic cysts and numerous benign and malignant tumors (e.g., hemangioblastomas of the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine, or pheochromocytoma). The condition would not explain this patient's skin and cognitive findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Individuals with tuberous sclerosis are at increased risk for subependymal giant cell astrocytoma. Tuberous sclerosis can also manifest with intellectual disability and seizures. However, cutaneous symptoms include hypopigmented ash-leaf spots rather than skinfold freckling and hyperpigmented café au lait spots. Additionally, patients usually have various benign tumors in specific areas (e.g., rhabdomyoma, ungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipoma) instead of this patient's disseminated tumors over the extremities and trunk.
questions.hint: This child presents with a seizure disorder, intellectual disability, developmental delay (walking well and using a fork and spoon should occur at around 14–15 months), axillary and inguinal freckling, café au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules), neurofibromas (soft, painless nodules), Lisch nodules (hyperpigmented iris nodules), and scoliosis, all of which indicate neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-minute episode of repetitive, involuntary, twitching movements of his left arm that occurred 1 hour ago. His symptoms began while playing with some toys. His parents say that he began to stand with support at 18 months and has recently started to walk with support. He speaks in bisyllables. He is at the 70th percentile for length and 80th percentile for weight. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a purple-pink patch over the right cheek that extends to the right eyelid. The right eyeball is firm. Neurologic examination shows left arm hypotonia and absent biceps reflex on the left side. Fundoscopy shows cupping of the right optic disc. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) can manifest in infants with a facial naevus flammeus, other features of this condition, such as macroglossia or overgrowth (> 97th percentile for height and weight) are not present in this patient. BWS also does not usually cause neurologic deficits or significant developmental delay.

B) INCORRECT:

While ataxia telangiectasia also causes facial skin changes, it usually manifests after 3 years of age with telangiectasias on the bulbar conjunctiva, the nasal bridge, the malar areas, external ears, and hard palate. This patient also does not have any other common manifestations of ataxia telangiectasia such as ataxia, oculomotor apraxia, and recurrent infections (due to immunodeficiency). Additionally, glaucoma, buphthalmos, and developmental delay are not typically seen in the condition.
Image Description:

Small dilated blood vessels with a threadlike appearance are visible.

This is the typical appearance of telangiectasia.

C) INCORRECT:

A diagnosis of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) requires at least two of the following criteria: epistaxis, telangiectasias, visceral lesions, or a first-degree relative with HHT. Telangiectasias associated with HHT can have macular appearance similar to the lesion seen in this patient, but telangiectasias are more commonly found on the lips, tongue, buccal mucosa, and fingertips. Seizures and developmental delay are not seen in the syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has several characteristics of Sturge-Weber syndrome. Most patients with the disorder are born with a naevus flammeus (port-wine stain), which usually lies over the region of the trigeminal nerve. The left-sided focal seizures, hypotonia, and absent reflexes are likely due to a right-sided leptomeningeal angioma, which classically occurs on the same side as the naevus flammeus. Vascular malformations within the eye lead to increased intraocular pressure and early-onset glaucoma. Patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome require anticonvulsants for seizure prophylaxis and regular ophthalmological screening. The naevus flammeus may be treated with laser therapy.

See “Overview of neurocutaneous syndromes” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) is characterized by the formation of tumors, including hemangioblastomas and fluid-filled cysts in different parts of the body. The formation of hemangioblastomas in the brain may lead to neurological deficits and focal seizures, but the onset of symptoms occurs later in life, typically in young adulthood. The condition is not associated with the skin lesions seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome (KTS) may cause a naevus flammeus, but it usually occurs in the lower extremities. KTS is also associated with varicosities and hypertrophy of the limb with the naevus flammeus.

G) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) can rarely manifest with infantile seizures. However, café au lait spots or macules associated with NF1 are usually brown rather than purple or red. The diagnosis of NF1 requires any two of the following: six or more café au lait spots, at least two neurofibromas, axillary or inguinal freckling, optic gliomas, Lisch nodules on the iris, a distinctive bony lesion (e.g., sphenoid dysplasia, cortical thinning of long bones), or a family history of NF1 in a first-degree relative.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

H) INCORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis can present with infantile seizures, developmental delay, and ash-leaf spots on physical examination. However, unlike the purple-red facial patch in this patient, the ash-leaf macule of tuberous sclerosis is hypopigmented, does not blanch with pressure, and more commonly occurs on the trunk or extremities.
questions.hint: This boy presents with a focal seizure, developmental delay, naevus flammeus (purple-pink patch over the cheek and eyelid) and signs of early-onset glaucoma (buphthalmos, cupping of the optic disc).

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of blood in the urine and fatigue. He also has had a 5.0-kg (11-lb) weight loss during the past month. Physical examination shows pallor and cachexia. A nontender right flank mass is palpated. A CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows a 5-cm right upper pole renal mass and several pulmonary lesions. A biopsy specimen of an affected area of the lung is obtained. A photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen is shown. Molecular evaluation of the specimen is most likely to show which of the following genetic changes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

NF1 gene inactivation causes neurofibromatosis type 1. This condition classically manifests with café au lait spots, neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules, all of which are absent in this patient. Additionally, renal and pulmonary involvement is uncommon. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 have an increased risk of optic gliomas and pheochromocytoma, but not RCC.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

PKD1 gene mutations are the most common cause of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Typical disease manifestations include enlarged kidneys (due to extensive bilateral renal cysts), hepatic cysts, and chronic hypertension, which are absent in this patient. The incidence of RCC in patients with ADPKD does not appear to be increased compared with the general population.

C) CORRECT:

Deletions of the VHL tumor suppressor gene are a common cause of both sporadic and familial renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Most cases of RCC are sporadic, although a small percentage are associated with VHL gene deletions in hereditary disorders such as von Hippel-Lindau disease. Histologic examination of tissue shows polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm due to the accumulation of lipids and carbohydrates (clear cells). Gross specimens often appear yellow as a result of high lipid content.

For diagnosis of localized RCC, total/partial nephrectomy is preferred over tissue biopsy, as it allows the diagnosis to be definitively established and is an effective treatment option that minimizes the risk of bleeding and tumor seeding. In patients with suspected metastases, a biopsy of the (suspicious) metastatic lesion is necessary for establishing the diagnosis and confirming the stage of cancer.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; coronal plane) of patient with a history of renal cell carcinoma

A large mass with peripheral enhancement (blue overlay) and central necrosis (yellow overlay) arises from the mid pole of the right kidney. Soft tissue density (red overlay) visible in the perinephric space raises concern for extracapsular extension. A large pleural effusion (outline) accompanied by passive atelectasis (green overlay) depresses the right hemidiaphragm.

A : calcified abdominal aorta; C: colon; K: left kidney; L: liver

D) INCORRECT:

MYCL1 gene amplification is implicated in the pathogenesis of lung cancer (especially small cell lung cancer). This patient's signs, symptoms, and histologic findings suggest a diagnosis of clear cell RCC. The presence of multiple pulmonary lesions on CT scan represents metastatic disease, not primary lung disease. Also, MYCL1 amplification does not play a role in the pathogenesis of RCC.

E) INCORRECT:

TSC1 gene insertions cause tuberous sclerosis (TSC), which commonly manifests with renal angiomyolipomas and can affect the lungs. However, TSC causes diffuse, interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, not discrete lesions. Additionally, TSC typically also manifest with intellectual disability, epilepsy, and skin findings such as ash-leaf spots, shagreen patches, or angiofibromas which are not seen in this patient. Less than 5% of patients with TSC develop RCC.

F) INCORRECT:

WT1 gene deletion is associated with the development of nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor), which can present with a palpable, unilateral flank mass, hematuria, and pulmonary metastases, as seen in this patient. However, histologic examination of nephroblastoma typically shows embryonic glomerular structure, not clear cells. Additionally, this tumor rarely occurs in the adult population.
questions.hint: Fatigue, hematuria, weight loss, and a palpable renal mass are highly suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The lung is a common site of metastasis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. His father notes that the boy has several pigmented areas on his skin and a few fleshy bumps. He has also had some blurred vision in his left eye. He has no history of serious medical illness. He lives at home with both parents and is up-to-date on all his immunizations. His father has similar skin findings. His mother has epilepsy and glaucoma. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity testing shows 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows multiple pigmented iris nodules. Examination of the skin shows eight brownish macules and numerous soft, non-tender, pedunculated lesions on the back, chest, and abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan is commonly used in the emergency setting to rapidly evaluate for trauma, space-occupying lesions, hydrocephalus, and intracranial bleeding. While individuals with NF1 are at increased risk of developing tumors of the central nervous system, a CT scan is not the best study for evaluating this patient's visual deficits.

B) CORRECT:

Optic glioma is the CNS tumor most commonly associated with NF1 and typically develops before the age of six years. Although this tumor is usually asymptomatic, patients may present with visual abnormalities, including proptosis, decreased color vision, and/or decreased visual acuity. All patients with NF1 and visual symptoms should undergo MRI of the brain with contrast for further evaluation. In addition, all children with NF1 should undergo an annual ophthalmologic examination to screen for optic glioma.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

EEG records electrical activity in the brain and is used to diagnose or screen for seizure activity. While individuals with NF1 are at increased risk of developing tumors of the central nervous system, which could cause seizure activity, this patient has no reported history of seizure and there is no indication to screen for seizures in NF1.

D) INCORRECT:

A B-scan ultrasound, also called a brightness scan, uses ultrasound waves to visualize ocular and orbital diseases. It is especially helpful in the detection of retinal hemangioblastomas, which are prevalent in von Hippel-Lindau disease, another neurocutaneous disorder. This patient has NF1 and should undergo a different diagnostic test to evaluate his visual disturbances.

E) INCORRECT:

Gonioscopy involves the placement of a lens (gonioscope) on the cornea to visualize the anterior chamber and chamber angle. It is considered the gold standard for diagnosis of glaucoma. Early glaucoma is common in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome but is uncommon in patients with NF1.
questions.hint: This child has multiple pigmented iris nodules (Lisch nodules), ≥ 6 hyperpigmented macules (café au lait spots), and numerous soft, pedunculated skin nodules (neurofibromas). These findings fulfill the diagnostic criteria for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches and blurry vision for the past 6 months. He also reports frequent episodes of vomiting over the last month. His father died of renal cell carcinoma at the age of 37 years. Examination shows 20/40 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling and growth of capillary vessels in the temporal peripheral retina. An MRI of the brain shows an infratentorial mass. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. In addition, this type of tumor most commonly develops in the first decade of life. Histology typically shows small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, medulloblastomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with Turcot's syndrome.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebellar vermis tissue (H&E stain)

Numerous small, blue, round cells with scant cytoplasm can be seen throughout the specimen (examples indicated by green overlay). Their nuclei vary in size and structure (nuclear pleomorphism) and many cells feature distinctly hyperchromatic nuclei.
The majority of the cells are arranged in concentric clusters around lighter central areas consisting of neuropil (examples indicated by yellow overlay). These clusters are referred to as Homer Wright rosettes.

These histopathological features, particularly the Homer Wright rosettes, are characteristic of a medulloblastoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Pilocytic astrocytomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. Moreover, this type of tumor most commonly develops in patients younger than 20 years of age. Histology typically shows Rosenthal fibers and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, pilocytic astrocytomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebellar tissue (H&E stain)

There are numerous bipolar cells, composed of a central basophilic nucleus with eosinophilic pilocytic processes (examples indicated in green) arising from either end. The pilocytic processes are arranged in bundles, which resemble matted hair. The bright red-pink bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions (examples indicated by black arrowheads) in astrocytes and indicate intense gliosis (Rosenthal fibers).

These are the characteristic features of pilocytic astrocytoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas can present with headache and vomiting, as seen here. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is located in the supratentorial (i.e., suprasellar) region. Moreover, craniopharyngiomas are usually associated with bitemporal hemianopsia, hyperprolactinemia, and hypopituitarism, all of which are absent here. Histology typically shows metaplastic squamous cells or reticular epithelial cells, calcifications, cysts, and keratin nodules, none of which are seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, craniopharyngiomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tissue sample (HPS stain; intermediate magnification)

Trabeculae and nests of squamous epithelium (examples indicated by yellow overlay) with palisading cells (examples indicated by blue hatched overlay) are visible.
Additionally, there are multiple cysts (examples indicated by yellow hatched overlay), nodules of anuclear ghost cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) containing wet keratin, and calcifications (examples indicated by blue outline) .

This is the typical histological appearance of an adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma.

D) INCORRECT:

Glioblastomas can present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema), as seen in this patient. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is located in the cerebral hemispheres (i.e., supratentorial). Consequently, symptoms such as seizures, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes are common, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, the median age of onset is between 65–75 years of age. Histology typically shows pleomorphic anaplastic cells that form pseudopalisades and positive staining for glial fibrillary acidic protein, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, glioblastomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cerebral tissue specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A high number and density of highly pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei are visible (examples indicated by arrowheads. These cells are aggregated around the periphery of the necrotic zone (green overlay), forming a nuclear pseudopalisading architecture.

These are the characteristic features of glioblastoma multiforme.

E) INCORRECT:

Oligodendrogliomas can present with headache and vomiting. However, as opposed to this patient's tumor, this type of neoplasm is most commonly located in the cerebral hemispheres (i.e., supratentorial). Consequently, symptoms such as seizures, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes are common, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, the median age of onset is between 40–50 years of age. Histology typically shows fried egg cells and a chicken-wire pattern of capillary anastomoses, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, oligodendrogliomas are not a manifestation of von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of brain tissue (H&E stain; very high magnification)

Monomorphic cells with enlarged, round/oval nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of unstained cytoplasm, which is an artifact of processing, are visible (green overlay). Thin blood vessels with an interlacing pattern are also visible (yellow overlay).

These are the typical features of oligodendroglioma.

F) CORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are rare, highly vascularized, infratentorial brain tumors, that may occur sporadically or as a manifestation of VHL disease. As in this case, patients often present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). Hemangioblastomas are further associated with polycythemia, caused by paraneoplastic erythropoietin production. Histology shows densely packed, thin-walled capillary vessels surrounded by large stromal cells with intracytoplasmic lipid inclusions. VHL-associated tumors most commonly occur in early adulthood and include hemangioblastomas of the spine, cerebellum, and retina (commonly bilateral and peripherally located, as seen here), renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic cysts.

G) INCORRECT:

Intracranial ependymomas, which are commonly located in the infratentorial region, may present with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, blurred vision, papilledema). However, they are not associated with retinal vascular changes. Moreover, this type of tumor most commonly develops in early childhood. Histology typically shows perivascular pseudorosettes and rod-shaped blepharoplasts, which are not seen in this patient's photomicrograph. Finally, ependymomas are not a manifestation of VHL disease but instead are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

There is an abnormally high number of cells with round nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Some cells are arranged in a spoke-and-wheel pattern, surrounding an empty central space. Such patterns are called ependymal rosettes (example indicated by green overlay). Other cells are arranged concentrically around blood vessels, producing a similar appearance (perivascular pseudorosettes; example indicated yellow overlay).

These are typical histopathological features of ependymoma.
questions.hint: This patient presents with an infratentorial brain tumor and abnormal capillary growth in the retina. In combination with a family history of renal cell carcinoma, this raises suspicion for von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of right lower extremity weakness, worsening headaches, abdominal pain, dark urine, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss for the past 2 months. His teachers report that he has not been paying attention in class and his grades have been worsening. He has a history of infantile seizures. Physical examination shows a palpable abdominal mass and left costovertebral angle tenderness. Neurological examination shows decreased strength of the right lower limb. He has several acne-like angiofibromas around the nose and cheeks. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A port wine stain in the V1-V2 trigeminal nerve distribution is characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS), which also causes neurologic disturbances such as seizures, intellectual disability, and focal neurological deficits (e.g., paresis, visual field defects). Although this patient's history of seizures, poor attention and declining performance at school could represent neurological manifestations of SWS, angiofibromas on the nose and cheeks and renal involvement (as indicated by hematuria) would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma is a tumor associated with Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL). Other tumors that can occur in VHL include hemangioblastomas (most often in the cerebellum, spinal cord, and/or retina), renal cell carcinoma, and pancreatic cysts and tumors. Although this patient has clinical features that can be caused by VHL (headaches, hematuria, abdominal mass, and left costovertebral angle tenderness), angiofibromas on the nose and cheeks would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Lisch nodules are an ophthalmologic feature of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). This condition is characterized by café au lait macules, neurofibromas, and optic gliomas. NF1 can manifest with seizures and cognitive deficits and is associated with certain tumors such as nephroblastomas, which manifest with hematuria and a palpable abdominal mass. However, this patient has angiofibromas of the nose and cheeks, which are not expected in NF1.
Image Description:

Right eye

Multiple brown-yellow, well-defined, and partly confluent papules (hamartomas) are visible on the iris.

These lesions are called Lisch nodules and can be seen in the vast majority of individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

D) CORRECT:

Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma is a brain tumor associated with tuberous sclerosis (TSC). Other common manifestations of TSC that this patient could develop include shagreen patches, ash-leaf spots, benign cysts, and renal cell carcinoma. This patient's infantile seizures were likely caused by “tubers” (cortical tumors) in the brain.

E) INCORRECT:

Vestibular schwannoma is a brain tumor that is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), particularly if there is bilateral involvement. The condition is typically diagnosed when tumors appear in late adolescence or early adulthood. While subcutaneous lesions (usually schwannomas or neurilemomas) can be present in NF2, this patient's angiofibromas around the nose and cheeks would not be expected. Moreover, this patient's findings indicate renal, behavioral, and cognitive abnormalities, which are inconsistent with a diagnosis of NF2.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.
questions.hint: This boy's combination of facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum), signs of angiomyolipomas (abdominal mass, macrohematuria), a history of infantile seizures, and signs of a potential brain tumor (i.e., focal neurologic deficits indicated by decreased limb strength, declining performance, poor attention) indicates tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after losing consciousness. His parents report that he collapsed and then had repetitive, twitching movements of the right side of his body that lasted approximately one minute. He recently started to walk with support. He speaks in bisyllables and has a vocabulary of almost 50 words. Examination shows a large purple-colored patch over the left cheek. One week later, he dies. Which of the following is the most likely finding on autopsy of the brain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraparenchymal cysts are a common finding in neurocysticercosis. While neurocysticercosis can manifest with seizures, it is not associated with cutaneous findings or intellectual disability. Moreover, neurocysticercosis takes 3–5 years to develop after initial Taenia solium infection and therefore would be unlikely in a 3-year-old child.

B) INCORRECT:

Periventricular calcifications are a common feature of congenital CMV infection, which can manifest with seizures and skin findings. However, petechiae and blueberry muffin rash would be expected rather than a port-wine stain. Moreover, this patient does not have other features of congenital CMV infection such as hearing loss or chorioretinitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Brainstem gliomas are a common finding in neurofibromatosis type 1, which can present with seizures, developmental delay, and skin findings. However, café au lait spots and neurofibromas would be expected rather than a port-wine stain. Moreover, this patient would be expected to have other features of neurofibromatosis type 1 such as optic gliomas, pheochromocytomas, and Lisch nodules.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has several characteristics of Sturge-Weber syndrome, a congenital disorder that affects the capillaries and commonly manifests with developmental delay and port-wine stain. Sturge-Weber syndrome is associated with vascular malformations in the choroid and CNS, including leptomeningeal angiomas, which are typically located ipsilateral to the port-wine stain and can cause seizures.

Sturge-Weber syndrome is also associated with early-onset glaucoma secondary to abnormal blood vessels of the eye.

E) INCORRECT:

Small benign tumors such as subependymal giant cell astrocytomas are commonly found in tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis can manifest with infantile spasms, seizures, skin findings, and intellectual disability. However, the skin findings typically consist of adenoma sebaceum, ash leaf spots, and/or Shagreen patches rather than the port-wine stain seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is associated with somatic mutation of the GNAQ gene.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of clumsiness and difficulty walking. She began to walk at 12 months and continues to have difficulty standing still without support. She also appears to have difficulty grabbing objects in front of her. Over the past year, she has had 5 episodes of sinusitis requiring antibiotic treatment and was hospitalized twice for bacterial pneumonia. Physical examination shows an unstable, narrow-based gait and several hyperpigmented skin patches. Serum studies show decreased levels of IgA and IgG and an increased level of alpha-fetoprotein. Over the next 5 years, which of the following complications is this patient most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic eczema is expected to develop in patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). While this condition could account for this patient's history of repeated infections, laboratory studies usually show increased (not decreased) IgA levels. Moreover, WAS does not cause neurological symptoms such as ataxia. Finally, because the condition is x-linked recessive, it would be very unlikely to affect a female patient.

B) CORRECT:

Conjunctival telangiectasias are a hallmark of the inherited syndrome ataxia telangiectasia (AT) and typically develop before the age of 5 years. Telangiectasias may also appear on other areas of exposed skin, particularly the face. The decreased serum levels of immunoglobulins predispose to infections, particularly of the respiratory tract. AT is due to an autosomal recessive mutation in the ATM gene, which assists in DNA break repair (nonhomologous end joining).

This patient also presents with café-au-lait spots (hyperpigmented skin patches). These are common in AT as well as other neurocutaneous conditions, e.g., neurofibromatosis type 1.
Image Description:

Medial angle of the left eye showing severely dilated blood vessels on the conjunctiva (conjunctival telangiectasia).

Conjunctival telangiectasias are a clinical finding of ataxia telangiectasia (Louis-Bar syndrome), a rare neurocutaneous syndrome

C) INCORRECT:

Pes cavus and other musculoskeletal abnormalities (e.g., kyphoscoliosis) are commonly observed early on in patients with Friedreich ataxia (FA). In contrast to the ataxia seen here, FA usually manifests with a staggering wide-based gait with onset in adolescence. Further symptoms include spastic paralysis and decreased vibration sensation, proprioception, and reflexes. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and diabetes are also strongly associated with FA, whereas immunodeficiency would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac rhabdomyoma rarely develops sporadically but can be seen in individuals with tuberous sclerosis (TS). While children with TS may have an impaired gait as a result of central nervous system hamartomas, immunodeficiency (as evidenced by this patient's repeated infections and low immunoglobulins) would not be expected. Moreover, this patient's hyperpigmented skin patches are not consistent with the skin findings seen in TS (i.e., adenoma sebaceum, ash leaf spots, and Shagreen patches).

E) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease is associated with selective IgA deficiency. As a result, affected patients may present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections in conjunction with or instead of the classic diarrhea and malabsorption. However, this patient has both IgA and IgG deficiency, which is not associated with celiac disease. This diagnosis also fails to explain the neurological symptoms and increased serum AFP seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is typically seen in older patients (usually > 60 years of age). Because many cases remain asymptomatic for a long period, it is often diagnosed late or incidentally. This patient has a hereditary condition that predisposes her to malignancies (especially acute leukemias and lymphomas), but that risk is not significantly increased in the next 5 years. Moreover, CLL is not one of the cancers typically associated with this patient's condition.
questions.hint: This toddler presents with cerebellar ataxia and recurrent sinopulmonary infection along with IgG and IgA deficiency and elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). This constellation of findings strongly suggests an underlying mutation in the ATM gene.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of decreased hearing, dizziness, and ringing in his right ear for the past 6 months. Physical examination shows multiple soft, yellow plaques and papules on his arms, chest, and back. There is sensorineural hearing loss and weakness of facial muscles bilaterally. His gait is unsteady. An MRI of the brain shows a 3-cm mass near the right internal auditory meatus and a 2-cm mass at the left cerebellopontine angle. The abnormal cells in these masses are most likely derived from which of the following embryological structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The neural tube gives rise to CNS glial cells (e.g., oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, ependymal cells), which are the glial cells of CN I and CN II. The neural tube does not give rise to Schwann cells, which are the glial cells of cranial nerves III–XII. Optic gliomas, which occur in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), are derived from astrocytes. NF1 can present similarly with cutaneous neurofibromas, but the absence of cafe-au-lait spots on physical examination and the presence of bilateral acoustic neuromas suggests a diagnosis of type 2 rather than NF1. NF2 is typically associated with optic nerve meningiomas rather than optic nerve gliomas.

B) INCORRECT:

The surface ectoderm gives rise to the anterior pituitary, external auditory canal, and inner ear structures (e.g., cochlea, vestibule, semicircular ducts) as well as glands of the skin, the parotid glands, and ameloblasts. It does not give rise to neurons or glial cells. Craniopharyngiomas arise from the remnant of the Rathke's pouch, which is a surface ectodermal derivative. They occur in the midline above the sella turcica and present typically during childhood with headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, and/or symptoms of hyperprolactinemia.

C) CORRECT:

Schwann cells are formed from neural crest cells, which arise from the lateral border of the neural plate (neuroectoderm) and migrate along somites to different parts of the body. Other structures derived from neural crest cells are neurons of cranial nerves III to XII, peripheral nerve neurons (both somatic and autonomic), skull bones, pia and arachnoid mater, odontoblasts, laryngeal cartilage, adrenal medulla, melanocytes, aorticopulmonary septum, and endocardial cushion. An immunohistochemical marker of neural crest cells is S-100, which is positive in melanomas, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, and schwannomas.

D) INCORRECT:

The notochord induces the formation of the neuroectoderm from the primitive ectoderm. The lateral border of the neuroectoderm will give rise to the embryological precursor of Schwann cells, but the notochord itself does not give rise to any neurological structure. It only forms the nucleus pulposus of the vertebral disc.

E) INCORRECT:

The mesoderm gives rise to bones, muscles (smooth, skeletal, and cardiac), connective tissue (including serosal linings of body cavities, e.g., peritoneum, pericardium, pleura) and dura mater), lymphatics, blood vessels, spleen, kidneys, adrenal cortex, and gonads. It does not form neurons or glial cells.
questions.hint: The bilateral masses in this patient causing sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo are acoustic neuromas, which arise from Schwann cells of CN VIII. Compression of the adjacent CN VII causes facial weakness. The combination of multiple cutaneous neurofibromas with bilateral acoustic neuromas is pathognomic of neurofibromatosis type 2.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up appointment. He has a seizure disorder treated with valproic acid. He has always had difficulties with his schoolwork. He was able to walk independently at the age of 2 years and was able to use a fork and spoon at the age of 3 years. Ophthalmic examination shows hyperpigmented iris nodules bilaterally. A photograph of his skin examination findings is shown. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vestibular schwannomas, especially bilaterally, are classically associated with neurofibromatosis type 2. NF2 typically presents with complications of schwannomas (e.g., hearing loss or balance problems) and may cause other CNS tumors (e.g., meningioma). Hyperpigmented iris nodules and cognitive impairment, as seen in this patient, are not associated with NF2.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemangioblastomas are associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease. Affected patients generally present with renal and pancreatic cysts along with numerous benign and malignant tumors (e.g., hemangioblastomas of the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine; pheochromocytoma; and bilateral renal cell carcinoma). The condition, however, would not explain this patient's skin and cognitive findings.
Image Description:

MRI head (with contrast; axial view)

A brightly enhancing, sharply delimited nodular mass (white arrow) with nonenhancing, cystic areas is visible within the right cerebellar hemisphere.

These findings are consistent with cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

C) CORRECT:

Pheochromocytomas are classically associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Patients with NF1 are also at increased risk for optic gliomas, especially as children. Hereditary pheochromocytomas are also associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease and multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2A, MEN 2B).
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

D) INCORRECT:

Leptomeningeal angiomas are seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. Affected patients may suffer from recurrent seizures owing to these intracranial angiomas. Intellectual disability is also common. However, the distinguishing cutaneous manifestation of this condition is the port wine stain. This patient instead has hyperpigmented macules and pigmented iris nodules, neither of which are seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac rhabdomyomas are classically associated with tuberous sclerosis, which can also present with intellectual disability and seizures. However, cutaneous symptoms include hypopigmented ash-leaf spots but not hyperpigmented café au lait spots.
questions.hint: This boy presents with a seizure disorder, intellectual disability, developmental delay (walking well and using a fork and spoon should occur at ∼ 14–15 months), café au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules), and hyperpigmented iris nodules (Lisch nodules), all of which are consistent with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with a seizure disorder and cognitive delay is brought to the physician because of progressively worsening right lower extremity weakness for the past 6 months. He does not make eye contact and sits very close to his mother. Physical examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Neurological examination shows decreased strength in the right lower leg with normal strength in the other extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows several multinodular, calcified lesions in the retina bilaterally. A photograph of his skin findings is shown. This patient's condition is most likely due to a mutation in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17 causes neurofibromatosis type 1. NF type 1 is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome that is characterized by café-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules (pigmented iris hamartomas), neurofibromas (benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors), and optic pathway gliomas. Although this condition has many shared features with tuberous sclerosis, café-au-lait spots are hyperpigmented whereas ash-leaf spots are characteristically hypopigmented. Moreover, this patient's abnormal cardiac examination raises concern for cardiac rhabdomyoma, which is not associated with neurofibromatosis.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22 causes neurofibromatosis type 2. NF type 2 is a hereditary neurocutaneous syndrome that manifests in multiple cerebral and spinal tumors, such as acoustic schwannomas (which may be bilateral), gliomas, and meningiomas. This patient has cardiac and dermatologic findings that cannot be accounted for by neurofibromatosis type 2.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the GNAQ gene on chromosome 9 causes Sturge-Weber syndrome. This condition causes vascular malformations that affect the face, brain, and eyes, manifesting as the characteristic port-wine stain on the forehead and upper eyelid, along with seizures, intellectual and behavioral problems, and visual defects (episcleral hemangioma, glaucoma). This patient is lacking the characteristic port-wine stain, making this diagnosis very unlikely. Moreover, this patient's abnormal cardiac examination raises concern for cardiac rhabdomyoma, which is not associated with this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis is caused by either a mutation in the TSC1 gene on chromosome 9 or a TSC2 gene mutation on chromosome 16, both of which are tumor suppressor genes. This patient presents with several common features of the condition such as cognitive development delay, focal neurological signs (due to central nervous system hamartomas or giant cell astrocytomas), and cardiac anomalies (either structural or due to cardiac rhabdomyoma). Additionally, the image displays one of the classic dermatologic manifestations, ash-leaf spots (others include angiofibromas, Shagreen spots, and ungual fibromas).

E) INCORRECT:

The VHL gene on chromosome 3 is mutated in von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL). This condition can also present with retinal growths and focal neurological defects (due to intracranial neoplastic growths) but would not account for the presence of this patient's ash-leaf spots or heart murmur (likely attributable to cardiac rhabdomyoma). Other expected findings in VHL include hemangioblastoma, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma.
questions.hint: This patient is presenting with focal neurologic deficits, retinal hamartomas, a murmur consistent with mitral regurgitation, and ash-leaf hypopigmented lesions, all of which are characteristic of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Eight months ago, he was treated for bacterial pneumonia. Over the past 2 years, he has also had 7 episodes of fever and purulent nasal discharge, each lasting for 5 to 7 days. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs, and takes no medications. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 38.6ºC (101.5ºF), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Crackles are heard at the right lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,200/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
72%


Lymphocytes
19%


Platelet count
300,000/mm3



Serum



Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


C-reactive protein (CRP)
34.2 mg/L (N = 0.08–3.1)


IgA
30 mg/dL


IgE
undetectable


IgG
125 mg/dL


IgM
10 mg/dL


A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows right lower lobe consolidation. An HIV test is negative. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pathological fractures are common in patients with autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome (Job syndrome) because of decreased bone density caused by increased bone reabsorption. Job syndrome can also manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections due to a defect in neutrophil chemotaxis. This patient, however, has decreased rather than increased serum levels of IgE. Moreover, patients with Job syndrome usually present with coarse facies (e.g., broad nose, frontal bossing) and other dermatologic findings (e.g., severe eczema, noninflamed skin abscesses).

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal hypopigmentation due to oculocutaneous albinism can be seen in patients with Chédiak-Higashi syndrome, which also manifests with recurrent pyogenic infections. However, normal rather than low serum immunoglobulin levels are expected in these patients. Moreover, Chédiak-Higashi syndrome usually manifests with neutropenia and the peripheral blood smear typically shows giant cytoplasmic granules in granulocytes and platelets.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; very high magnification)

Inclusion bodies (examples indicated by arrows) and polymorphous nuclei (green overlay) can be seen within the leukocytes.

These findings are consistent with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

CVID is associated with an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders (e.g., immune thrombocytopenia, rheumatoid arthritis, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, autoimmune thyroiditis, vitiligo) as a result of immune system dysregulation. Patients with CVID are also at increased risk of developing lymphoma, gastric cancer, and bronchiectasis.

Selective IgA deficiency and Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome are other congenital immunodeficiencies associated with an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar ataxia is seen in patients with ataxia-telangiectasia, which can also manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and low serum levels of IgA, IgE, and IgG. However, low serum levels of IgM are not expected. Moreover, the age of onset is generally 6–18 months and ataxia-telangiectasia typically manifests with spider angiomas and other neurological features (e.g., chorea, dystonia, myoclonic jerks, oculomotor apraxia).

E) INCORRECT:

Left heart failure due to hypoplastic left heart syndrome can occur in patients with DiGeorge syndrome, which can also manifest with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and low serum IgM levels. However, low serum levels of IgA, IgG, and IgE are not expected. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical findings seen in patients with DiGeorge syndrome, such as facial anomalies (i.e., dysplastic ears, micrognathia, cleft palate), features of hypocalcemia (e.g., tetany), and an absent thymic shadow on chest x-ray.
questions.hint: This patient's history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections in combination with low serum levels of all immunoglobulins suggests common variable immunodeficiency (CVID).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of increasing flank pain and progressive fatigue. He has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during the past 2 months. His mother underwent surgery for pheochromocytoma at the age of 40. He has smoked 10 cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He is 186 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) and blood pressure is 144/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. There are firm palpable masses on both flanks. Fundoscopy of the right eye shows a 0.4-mm sized hemangioblastoma in the periphery of the left upper retinal quadrant and no other abnormalities. Fundoscopy of the left eye is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination including neurological examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 13,000/mm3, and serum creatinine concentration is 1.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows numerous red blood cells. An abdominal CT scan with contrast shows bilateral 5-cm renal masses with thickened irregular walls, variable enhancement, and calcifications. The patient is scheduled for bilateral partial nephrectomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test at this time?

choices.text: No screening is indicated at this time
MRI of the brain and spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

VHL disease is characterized by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumors. Therefore, regular screening for these potentially life-threatening conditions from the point of diagnosis is essential.

B) CORRECT:

In all patients with VHL disease older than 11 years, MRI of the brain and spine to screen for CNS hemangioblastoma is recommended at the time of diagnosis and biennially (i.e., every 2 years) if the initial MRI is normal. Hemangioblastomas, which are the most common tumors associated with VHL disease, most frequently occur in the cerebellum, brainstem, spine, and retina. CNS hemangioblastomas are the main cause of death in patients with VHL disease. Further manifestations of VHL disease include bilateral renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, endolymphatic sac tumors, renal, pancreatic, and/or adrenal cysts, and cystadenomas. Active surveillance guidelines that take into account the typical age of onset of associated lesions ensure early detection of these conditions. In a patient diagnosed with VHL disease, additional screening modalities include annual eye examination and blood pressure measurement from infancy, annual plasma/urinary metanephrines measurement starting at age 5 years, a biennial audiogram starting at age 11 years, biennial abdominal MRI starting at age 15 years, and a one-time MRI of the internal auditory canal in patients older than 15 years.

Any patient presenting with CNS or retinal hemangioblastoma before the age of 50 years should undergo testing for VHL disease.
Image Description:

MRI images (contrast-enhanced; T1-weighted) of a patient with Von-Hippel-Lindau syndrome.

Image A (brain; axial view) shows a tumor within the lateral aspect of the right cerebellum. It consists of an enhancing solid component (red overlay) and a larger, hypointense part representing a cystic component (blue overlay).

Image B (brain; sagittal view) shows a contrast-enhancing tumor (green overlay) between medulla oblongata and cerebellum, within the region of the foramen of Magendie/median aperture.

Image C (spine MRI; sagittal view) shows a hyperintense tumor (yellow overlay) within the dorsal/posterior spinal canal at the level of vertebra C5-C6.

Von-Hippel-Lindau syndrome is a hereditary disorder characterised by the development of tumors in multiple parts of the body. This includes hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system, such as in this example. Hemangioblastomas are highly vascular tumours, resulting in the intense enhancement demonstrated on these post contrast images. Peritumoural cysts are common in these tumors, and result from plasma ultrainfiltrate passing through the permeable tumor blood vessels.

C) INCORRECT:

Monitoring for osteoporosis, e.g., by dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) is recommended in adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). While NF1 has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and is also associated with pheochromocytoma, this condition typically manifests in childhood or adolescence with multiple neurofibromas, skin lesions (e.g., café au lait spots, axillary and inguinal freckling), Lisch nodules, seizures and/or focal neurologic signs, intellectual disability, and other tumors (e.g., nephroblastoma, optic pathway glioma). NF1 is not associated with retinal hemangioblastoma or renal cell carcinoma. This patient most likely has VHL disease, which is not associated with osteoporosis; therefore, routine DXA is not indicated.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid ultrasound to screen for medullary thyroid cancer is indicated in patients diagnosed with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). While approx. 40% of patients with MEN2 develop pheochromocytoma, this condition is not associated with retinal hemangioblastoma or renal cell carcinoma. This patient most likely has VHL disease, which is not associated with thyroid gland diseases; routine thyroid ultrasound is therefore not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography to screen for cardiac rhabdomyoma is recommended in children with tuberous sclerosis (TS) at the time of diagnosis and, if an asymptomatic rhabdomyoma is detected, subsequently every 1 to 3 years. While TS is also associated with renal cell carcinoma, this condition typically manifests in early childhood with infantile spasms or seizures, intellectual disability, and skin lesions (e.g., adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, shagreen patch). TS is not associated with retinal hemangioblastoma or pheochromocytoma. This patient most likely has VHL disease, which is not associated with cardiac diseases; routine echocardiography is therefore not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation and abdominal imaging findings indicate bilateral renal cell carcinoma. In combination with a retinal hemangioblastoma on fundoscopy and a family history of pheochromocytoma, this should raise concern for von-Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL disease).

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 3 years
Sex Assigned at Birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified 
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My son has a rash on his face.” 
History of Present Illness:

patient brought in by his mother because of a 1-year history of a progressively worsening rash
lesions started appearing around his nose and have increased in number; lesions are not itchy or painful
application of over-the-counter topical adapalene did not clear the lesions 
no fever, cough, or failure to thrive

Past Medical History:

infantile spasms diagnosed 2 years ago; well controlled with vigabatrin
Medications:

vigabatrin 
adapalene

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

mother: age 35 years, alive with no chronic conditions

father: deceased at age 36 years from inoperable giant cell astrocytoma

sister: age 5 years, no chronic conditions
brother: age 1 year, no chronic conditions

Psychosocial History:

lives with his mother and siblings
slight language delay but otherwise met all age-specific developmental milestones 

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.8°C (98.2°F)
105/min
27/min
100/58 mm Hg
