95.3 cm (3 ft 2 in)54th %ile
14.4 kg (31 lb 12 oz)52nd %ile
16 kg/m245th %ile



Appearance: no acute distress 
Skin: red-brown papulonodular lesions around the nose and cheeks; a cluster of five 3-cm irregularly shaped, rough, flesh-colored plaques on the lower back

HEENT: pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation; ocular movements intact; oral mucosa pink and moist
Neck: no lymphadenopathy or neck masses
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft, nontender; normoactive bowel sounds 
Extremities: no edema or tenderness; femoral pulses intact; no lymphadenopathy
Neurologic: alert and fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

TS follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, but spontaneous mutations are also possible. An echocardiogram is indicated in all patients with TS to rule out cardiac rhabdomyoma, which is present in > 50% of cases. Further diagnostic workup includes cerebral CT or MRI and abdominal MRI to evaluate for involvement of the brain (e.g., hamartomas, giant cell astrocytoma) and kidneys (e.g., renal cysts, angiomyolipoma, renal carcinoma). Since there is no curative treatment for TS, management focuses on clinical manifestations and includes seizure control and potential removal of tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

Applanation tonometry measures intraocular pressure (IOP). Certain tumors such as episcleral angioma can elevate IOP and cause early-onset glaucoma, but they are typically associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) rather than TS. The characteristic cutaneous manifestation of SWS is a nevus flammeus on the face.

C) INCORRECT:

Audiometry is used in the diagnosis of hearing loss. Certain tumors such as vestibular schwannomas can lead to sensorineural hearing loss, but they are typically associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 rather than TS. TS is not associated with hearing loss.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

D) INCORRECT:

An elevated plasma metanephrine concentration indicates a catecholamine-producing tumor, such as pheochromocytoma. These tumors are typically associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease rather than TS.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy is used to diagnose gastrointestinal tumors such as gastrointestinal stromal tumors. These tumors are typically associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 rather than TS. TS is not associated with any conditions that affect the gastrointestinal tract.
questions.hint: Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum), a shagreen patch, and a history of infantile spasms indicate tuberous sclerosis (TS).

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of hematuria. She denies any dysuria or urinary frequency but reports intermittent fevers and fatigue for the past month.
She has a brother who was diagnosed with an abdominal tumor that caused hypertension 6 months ago at the age of 37 and what she calls an “eye tumor” when he was young. She did not know her father but was told he died of an unknown cancer in his late 40s. Her urinalysis is positive for blood but otherwise negative.
Which one of the following evaluations is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is appropriate when a lower urinary-tract cancer is suspected.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine culture is not helpful in patients with hematuria unless there are other clinical or urinalysis findings suggesting infection.

C) CORRECT:

Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a rare, autosomal dominant familial cancer syndrome consisting chiefly of retinal angioma, hemangioblastoma of the central nervous system, pheochromocytoma, and clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma. Among patients with von Hippel-Lindau disease, the mean age at diagnosis of renal-cell carcinoma is approximately 44 years, which is significantly older than the mean age at diagnosis of cerebellar hemangioblastoma and retinal angioma.

A patient who has a family history suggesting Von Hippel-Lindau and who presents with hematuria should have cross-sectional imaging of the kidneys. An enhancing renal mass on CT would be indicative of the presence of renal-cell carcinoma. Renal-cell carcinoma can manifest as hematuria, flank pain, or a palpable abdominal mass. Patients may also present with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, or anemia.

Key learning point: The most appropriate imaging study to perform in a patient suspected of having renal-cell carcinoma is CT of the abdomen and pelvis.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is not as sensitive or as specific as CT, which allows for the assessment of local invasiveness, lymph-node involvement, and other metastases.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine urine cytology is costly and of very limited clinical value as a first-line investigation for patients with hematuria.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought in by his grandmother for a well-child examination. He is new to your practice, and you have not yet received his medical records. His grandmother says that he is undergoing evaluation for speech delay but has no significant medical history. She notes a family history of cancer on his father’s side but has no further details. When you note some pigmented spots on his skin, she says that they have been there “for some time” and do not seem to bother him.
The patient’s height and weight are at the 25th percentile for age, and his vital signs are within normal limits. Skin examination is notable for several hyperpigmented macules and patches on the trunk and back (figure) with an additional patch noted on the thigh. There are also smaller dot-like hyperpigmented macules evident in the skin folds of the axilla and inguinal regions. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following tumors is this patient at greatest risk for developing, given his skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sturge-Weber syndrome is a vascular disorder characterized by a capillary malformation, or port-wine stain, in the forehead/upper eyelid region and by aberrant vasculature within the eye (potentially leading to glaucoma) and the brain. The abnormal formation and growth of blood vessels occurs within the leptomeninges and is referred to as leptomeningeal angioma; it can affect one or both sides of the brain and impede blood flow in the brain, leading to atrophy and calcification in the brain below the angioma.

B) INCORRECT:

Although optic gliomas can occur in patients with NF1, they are less common than neurofibromas.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s skin findings are suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder. NF1 is diagnosed when a patient meets at least two of the following criteria:

• Six or more hyperpigmented flat lesions (café au lait macules), with each measuring >5 mm in diameter if the patient is a child or >15 mm if the patient is an adolescent or adult
• Freckling in the axillary or inguinal regions
• Two or more raised melanocytic hamartomas of the iris (Lisch nodules)
• Two or more neurofibromas of any type or at least one plexiform neurofibroma
• Optic glioma
• One or more distinctive bony lesions (such as sphenoid dysplasia or thinning of the long-bone cortex) with or without pseudoarthrosis
• A first-degree relative with NF1

This patient has both café au lait macules on the trunk and freckling in the axillary and inguinal regions. Café au lait macules are often the first manifestation of NF1, appearing during infancy and then increasing in number throughout childhood. They are hyperpigmented compared with the surrounding skin and may be macules or patches.

Freckling in the axillary or inguinal regions is typically detected between the ages of 2 and 5, followed by Lisch nodules (which are pathognomonic of NF1) between the ages of 5 and 10.

Patients with NF1 are at increased risk for developing benign and malignant neoplasms throughout life. Neurofibromas, or peripheral nerve sheath tumors, are the most common type of benign tumor to occur in NF1. Cutaneous and subcutaneous neurofibromas do not usually manifest until late childhood or adolescence. Plexiform neurofibromas typically manifest in early childhood. Although optic gliomas can occur in patients with NF1, they are less common than neurofibromas.

Key learning point: Café au lait macules on the trunk and freckling in the axillary and inguinal regions are skin findings characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 1.

D) INCORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited neurocutaneous disorder whose characteristic skin findings can include a distinctive pigmented plaque on the forehead that is darker than the surrounding skin, ash-leaf spots (hypopigmented macules that are often elliptical in shape), shagreen patches (patches of skin with a texture similar to that of an orange peel), and facial angiofibromas (small skin-colored or pigmented papules, typically in a malar distribution). Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain (glioneuronal hamartomas or cortical tubers) and the heart.

E) INCORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited neurocutaneous disorder whose characteristic skin findings can include a distinctive pigmented plaque on the forehead that is darker than the surrounding skin, ash-leaf spots (hypopigmented macules that are often elliptical in shape), shagreen patches (patches of skin with a texture similar to that of an orange peel), and facial angiofibromas (small skin-colored or pigmented papules, typically in a malar distribution). Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain (glioneuronal hamartomas or cortical tubers) and the heart.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy is brought in for a well-child examination. He is a new patient to you. His parents have no major concerns and report that he has been generally healthy since birth. His growth has been appropriate, and he has been achieving his developmental milestones.
Physical examination reveals a pinkish-red vascular patch on the boy's face (figure) that his mother notes has been present since birth. It is growing with him, has always been flat, and does not seem to be pruritic, painful, or symptomatic in any way. His neurologic examination is normal.
Which one of the following sets of potential complications is a concern in this patient?

choices.text: Angiofibromas, hamartomas, and subependymal giant-cell tumors
Soft-tissue and limb hypertrophy and gastrointestinal bleeding

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis is associated with pigmented macules, known as café au lait spots, that may arise anywhere on the body. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) often have macrocephaly and develop peripheral neurofibromas; they may also have seizures, developmental delay, peripheral neuropathy, soft-tissue sarcomas, bone abnormalities, hypertension, and neurologic abnormalities. NF1 does not feature port-wine stains.

B) INCORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis is associated with angiofibromas of the face and hypopigmented macules (known as ash leaf spots and confetti macules) that are often found on the trunk. Complications of tuberous sclerosis include hamartomas, subependymal giant-cell tumors, seizures, cognitive deficits, and cardiovascular and ophthalmologic abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's birthmark is a capillary malformation known as a port-wine stain. Port-wine stains are large pink or red flat patches that are present at birth. Although they may be found anywhere on the body, the face and neck are the most common locations. Port-wine stains may be unilateral or bilateral, focal or extensive. They enlarge as the child grows and tend to become darker over time.

Although a port-wine stain may be an isolated finding in an otherwise healthy child, it may also be associated with syndromes such as Sturge-Weber and Klippel-Trénaunay, among others. The location of this patient's port-wine stain raises concern for Sturge-Weber syndrome, a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by port-wine stains on the forehead and associated vascular malformations in the eye and brain. Children with Sturge-Weber syndrome may have headaches, seizures, visual-field defects, glaucoma, and developmental delays with variable neurologic and cognitive deterioration. Newer data show that the forehead location is the highest risk area, as it correlates with an embryologic placode that, if affected early in development by a GNAQ mutation, may potentially result in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Treatment of Sturge-Weber syndrome is directed at the individual components of the syndrome — pulsed dye laser therapy to lighten port-wine stains, antiepileptics for seizures, and ophthalmologic interventions as necessary for glaucoma. Importantly, port-wine stains involving any portion of the eyelid (upper or lower), even in isolation (distinct from concern for Sturge-Weber syndrome), should be evaluated by an ophthalmologist because of the risk of isolated glaucoma.

Key learning point: The presence of a port-wine stain on the forehead is suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Ataxia-telangiectasia is a neurocutaneous syndrome associated with telangiectasias, particularly on the face (in and around the eyes and ears), chest, and arms. It is associated with progressive cerebellar ataxia, immune deficiencies, and increased risk for malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome also features capillary malformations (port-wine stains), but they appear on the extremities and are associated with underlying vascular malformations of the venous and/or lymphatic systems. There may also be soft-tissue and bone abnormalities of the affected limb. Deep-vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and gastrointestinal bleeding are possible complications.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old girl is brought in by her mother for a well-child check. Her history is significant for a cardiac rhabdomyoma detected on prenatal ultrasound and the presence of four hypopigmented macules scattered over her trunk at birth. Her father also has a history of hypopigmented areas on his chest and abdomen, as well as seizures during childhood and kidney disease recognized during adulthood.
On physical examination, the patient has normal vital signs, a 1/6 soft systolic ejection murmur, normal pulses, and scattered hypomelanotic macules on her trunk and lower extremities. She also has a dark, thick, dimpled patch on her lower back. Her neurologic examination is normal for her age.
The mother has questions about how her daughter’s disorder is inherited and whether her other children, who have a different biological father, require screening.
What is the inheritance pattern of this disorder?

choices.text: Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetrance and consistent clinical expressivity
Autosomal recessive with incomplete penetrance and variable clinical expressivity
X-linked with incomplete penetrance and consistent clinical expressivity
Autosomal recessive with complete penetrance and variable clinical expressivity
Autosomal dominant with complete penetrance and variable clinical expressivity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If a disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion but with incomplete penetrance and consistent clinical expressivity, then some individuals who have the pathogenic variant will not exhibit any symptoms - and those who do will all exhibit the same symptoms. An example of this is breast cancer due to inheritance of BRCA1; about 80% of women with the pathogenic variant will develop the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Gaucher disease is an example of an autosomal recessive disease with incomplete penetrance and variable expressivity. The most common pathogenic variant associated with Gaucher disease has low penetrance and exhibits extensive phenotype heterogeneity, even in the homozygous state.

C) INCORRECT:

If a disease is inherited in an X-linked fashion, it will typically occur only in males. X-linked dominant chondrodysplasia punctata is an example of an X-linked disease with incomplete penetrance and consistent clinical expressivity. Skewed X-inactivation causes the incomplete penetrance in female carriers.

D) INCORRECT:

If a disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, then two pathogenic variants (one from each parent) are necessary for the disease to occur. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an example of an autosomal recessive disease with complete penetrance and variable expressivity. The most common pathogenic variant associated with CF (⧍F508) will lead to disease in all patients who have inherited two copies, but affected individuals will vary in the symptoms they exhibit and in the severity of their disease.

E) CORRECT:

This patient meets clinical diagnostic criteria for tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). Clinical diagnosis requires two major criteria or the combination of one major criterion with two or more minor criteria. The major clinical criteria are cardiac rhabdomyoma, hypomelanotic macules, shagreen patch, angiofibromas, ungual fibromas, multiple retinal hamartomas, cortical dysplasias, subependymal nodules, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, angiomyolipomas, and lymphangioleiomyomatosis. The minor criteria are dental enamel pits, “confetti” skin lesions, intraoral fibromas, retinal achromic patch, multiple renal cysts, and nonrenal hamartomas.

TSC can also be diagnosed by identifying a pathogenic variant in either the TSC1 gene (located on chromosome 9q34) or the TSC2 gene (located on chromosome 16p.13.3). The disorder is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, such that having only one pathogenic variant is sufficient to cause disease. Two-thirds of cases are the result of a de novo pathogenic variant, and one-third are inherited from an affected parent.

Symptoms of TSC manifest in all individuals who have a pathogenic variant (complete penetrance), although which symptoms they have and how severe they are will vary (clinical expressivity), even in families with more than one person affected (high intrafamilial variability). Predicting which symptoms this patient will develop over her lifetime is difficult, but she can be counseled later in life that she has a 50% chance of passing the disease to each of her future children. Her mother can be counseled that the disease was likely inherited from the father’s side (given his history of symptoms) and that her other children (who reportedly have a different father) should not be affected.

Key learning point: A child presenting with multiple hypomelanotic macules, a cardiac rhabdomyoma, and a shagreen patch meets diagnostic criteria for tuberous sclerosis complex.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy is seen in the clinic for multiple light-brown macules on his trunk and small, flesh-colored nodules on his arms. He also has faint freckling in the axilla. His mother has the same condition but displays only numerous café-au-lait macules. The maternal grandfather has minimal skin findings. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17.
Which genetic phenomenon best explains the varying severity of features among these affected family members?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticipation involves earlier onset and increased severity of a genetic disorder in successive generations, typically seen in disorders with unstable repeat expansions, such as Huntington disease. The NF1 mutation does not exhibit this pattern, as the variability in clinical features among family members is due to variable expressivity, not generational worsening.

B) CORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17, which encodes neurofibromin, a protein that regulates cell growth. The disorder manifests with a range of symptoms, including café-au-lait macules, neurofibromas, and axillary freckling. The severity of these symptoms can vary significantly among individuals with the same mutation, even within the same family. This phenomenon, known as variable expressivity, occurs when a single genetic mutation results in different clinical outcomes. Factors such as modifier genes, epigenetic changes, and environmental influences contribute to this variability.

Key learning point: Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) is characterized by cafe-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and axillary freckling, and follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

C) INCORRECT:

Incomplete penetrance occurs when some individuals with a disease-causing mutation do not exhibit any clinical features. In this family, all affected individuals display some manifestations of NF1, such as café-au-lait spots or neurofibromas, indicating that the mutation is expressed in all carriers. The variability in severity is due to variable expressivity, not incomplete penetrance.

D) INCORRECT:

Genomic imprinting involves differential gene expression based on the parent of origin, as seen in disorders like Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes. The variability in NF1 clinical features among family members is not due to imprinting but rather to variable expressivity, where the same mutation leads to a spectrum of clinical findings influenced by genetic and environmental factors.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is evaluated in the clinic for multiple pigmented lesions on his trunk. Examination reveals six uniformly pigmented macules larger than 5 mm and numerous freckles in his axilla. He also has two small, soft protrusions on his arms. His father has similar lesions and had surgery for a benign tumor in his twenties. Vital signs are stable, and the remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following best describes the pattern of inheritance for this condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is caused by a mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17 and follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. A single mutated gene copy is sufficient to cause the disorder. Variable expressivity in NF1 means that clinical manifestations can vary significantly even within the same family. The presence of multiple café-au-lait spots, axillary freckling, cutaneous neurofibromas, and a positive family history are characteristic of NF1. This condition exhibits an autosomal dominant pattern with variable expressivity.

Key learning point: Neurofibromatosis type 1 is characterized by café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and axillary freckling, and follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitochondrial inheritance involves transmission from an affected mother, as mitochondrial DNA is maternally inherited. The father's similar clinical findings contradict this pattern. Mitochondrial disorders typically involve systemic features related to energy metabolism, not the skin lesions described.

C) INCORRECT:

Autosomal recessive disorders require two copies of a mutated gene for manifestation, typically with unaffected carrier parents. The affected father directly transmits the condition to his son, which is inconsistent with autosomal recessive inheritance. The clinical features suggest an autosomal dominant pattern.

D) INCORRECT:

X-linked recessive inheritance involves affected males inheriting the mutant allele from carrier mothers, with no male-to-male transmission. The affected father transmitting the condition to his son contradicts X-linked recessive inheritance. The clinical features and family history do not align with this pattern.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old girl brought to your clinic by her parents because of clumsiness and difficulty walking. She began walking at 12 months but continues to have difficulty standing still without support. Her parents have also noticed that she has trouble grabbing objects in front of her. Over the past year, she has had 5 episodes of sinusitis requiring antibiotics and has been hospitalized twice for bacterial pneumonia. On examination, she has an unstable, narrow-based gait and several hyperpigmented skin patches. Serum studies show decreased IgA and IgG levels and an increased alpha-fetoprotein level (>9.0 μg/L). Over the next 5 years, which one of the following complications is she most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac rhabdomyoma rarely develops sporadically but can be seen in individuals with tuberous sclerosis (TS). While children with TS may have an impaired gait as a result of central nervous system hamartomas, immunodeficiency (as evidenced by this patient's repeated infections and low immunoglobulins) would not be expected. Moreover, this patient's hyperpigmented skin patches are not consistent with the skin findings seen in TS (i.e., adenoma sebaceum, ash leaf spots, and Shagreen patches).

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic eczema is expected to develop in patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). While this condition could account for this patient's history of repeated infections, laboratory studies usually show increased (not decreased) IgA levels. Moreover, WAS does not cause neurological symptoms such as ataxia. Finally, because the condition is x-linked recessive, it would be very unlikely to affect a female patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pes cavus and other musculoskeletal abnormalities (e.g., kyphoscoliosis) are commonly observed early on in patients with Friedreich ataxia (FA). In contrast to the ataxia seen here, FA usually manifests with a staggering wide-based gait with onset in adolescence. Further symptoms include spastic paralysis and decreased vibration sensation, proprioception, and reflexes. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and diabetes are also strongly associated with FA, whereas immunodeficiency would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is typically seen in older patients (usually > 60 years of age). Because many cases remain asymptomatic for a long period, it is often diagnosed late or incidentally. This patient has a hereditary condition that predisposes her to malignancies (especially acute leukemias and lymphomas), but that risk is not significantly increased in the next 5 years. Moreover, CLL is not one of the cancers typically associated with this patient's condition.

E) CORRECT:

Conjunctival telangiectasias are a hallmark of the inherited syndrome ataxia telangiectasia (AT) and typically develop before the age of 5 years. Telangiectasias may also appear on other areas of exposed skin, particularly the face. The decreased serum levels of immunoglobulins predispose to infections, particularly of the respiratory tract. AT is due to an autosomal recessive mutation in the ATM gene, which assists in DNA break repair (nonhomologous end joining).

This patient also presents with café-au-lait spots (hyperpigmented skin patches). These are common in AT as well as other neurocutaneous conditions, e.g., neurofibromatosis type 1.

Key learning point: Ataxia-telangiectasia is characterized by progressive ataxia, immunodeficiency, elevated alpha-fetoprotein, and the development of conjunctival telangiectasias by early childhood.
Image Description:

Medial angle of the left eye showing severely dilated blood vessels on the conjunctiva (conjunctival telangiectasia).

Conjunctival telangiectasias are a clinical finding of ataxia telangiectasia (Louis-Bar syndrome), a rare neurocutaneous syndrome
questions.hint: This toddler presents with cerebellar ataxia and recurrent sinopulmonary infection along with IgG and IgA deficiency and elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). This constellation of findings strongly suggests an underlying mutation in the ATM gene.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening gait unsteadiness and bilateral hearing loss for 1 month. He has had intermittent tingling sensations on both cheeks over this time period. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Audiometry shows bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Genetic evaluation shows a mutation of a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22 that encodes merlin. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), an autosomal dominant syndrome caused by mutation of the NF1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 17. Other tumors that may occur in patients with NF1 include benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors originating from neural crest cells (neurofibromas), pheochromocytomas, and nephroblastomas. However, bilateral schwannomas are not associated with NF1. Moreover, patients with NF1 usually present with typical skin findings (due to melanocyte dysfunction) such as café au lait spots and axillary/inguinal freckling, as well as musculoskeletal findings (e.g., scoliosis, tall stature, and bone involvement) and Lisch nodules of the iris, none of which is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

The occurrence of (bilateral) renal cell carcinoma is associated with von Hippel‑Lindau disease (VHL), an autosomal dominant syndrome caused by a mutation to the tumor-suppressing Hippel-Lindau gene. This neurocutaneous syndrome is characterized by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumors, including hemangioblastomas (highly vascularized in the retina, cerebellum, brain stem, and spine), pheochromocytomas, and renal and pancreatic cysts. Bilateral schwannomas, however, are not a typical feature.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (with oral and IV contrast; axial plane) of patient with a history of renal cell carcinoma

A large mass with peripheral enhancement (blue overlay) and central necrosis (yellow overlay) arises from the mid pole of the right kidney.

A: abdominal aorta; C: colon; K: left kidney; P: pancreas

C) CORRECT:

Besides bilateral schwannomas, neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) often manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors, as well as meningiomas. Most meningiomas are slow-growing, and patients may therefore be asymptomatic for a prolonged period of time. If symptoms are present, they usually include general symptoms of CNS tumors (e.g., seizures) or more specific symptoms that depend on the tumor location (e.g., paraparesis and/or uncontrolled micturition if tumor arises from the falx cerebri).
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

D) INCORRECT:

Giant cell astrocytomas are frequently associated with tuberous sclerosis, an autosomal dominant syndrome that is caused by mutation of the TSC1 or TSC2 gene, which encode for hamartin or tuberin protein (both tumor suppressors), respectively. Other benign growths associated with tuberous sclerosis include hamartomas of the brain, cardiac rhabdomyomas, renal cysts, renal angiomyolipomas, and ungual fibromas. The brain lesions typically result in infantile spasms (head bobbing, flexor or extensor spasms in children < 3 years of age), seizures, and intellectual disability. Furthermore, skin manifestations, such as adenoma sebaceum, ash-leaf spots, and a Shagreen patch are commonly seen. However, schwannomas are not a feature of tuberous sclerosis and the condition is usually diagnosed before the age of 10 years.

E) INCORRECT:

Vascular malformations of the choroid and the CNS such as ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas are a typical feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome, a condition caused by somatic mosaic mutations in the GNAQ gene. The vascular malformations may result in seizures, early-onset glaucoma (due to increased intraorbital pressure), and intellectual disability. Patients also often present with a facial nevus flammeus (port-wine stain). However, schwannomas are not associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

F) INCORRECT:

Telangiectasias on the face and conjunctivae are typical findings in patients with ataxia telangiectasia, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DNA-repair ATM gene. Other manifestations include progressive cerebellar ataxia (due to atrophy of the cerebellar vermis), athetosis, immunodeficiency (e.g., increased susceptibility to ear infections, sinusitis, and pneumonia), and increased sensitivity to radiation resulting in a higher risk of malignancies (e.g. non-Hodgkin lymphoma, leukemia). However, the finding of bilateral schwannomas is not typical in patients with ataxia telangiectasia. Furthermore, symptoms typically present during early childhood.
questions.hint: The patient's unsteadiness, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and midface paresthesia are consistent with bilateral compression of CN V and CN VIII. This is usually caused by bilateral vestibular schwannomas, a hallmark feature of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2). NF-2 is an autosomal dominant syndrome that it is caused by a mutation in the NF-2 gene on chromosome 22, which produces merlin, a tumor suppressor.
